This is like a sudoku, but worse and colourful. If you want a better sudoku, just play Sagrada.

Mogul Scale: 1/A

Rules are unclear regarding color placement and it implies you should place one color per line, but the example pictures show the same color repeated per line. Very confusing and hard to play the game with a good strategy to win because the rule is not explicit. I hated this game, then thought it was okay, now back to hating it. Dumping the game because I don’t even want to bother selling it.
Absolutely overrated. The most boring board game ever. Don't waste your money on 100 squares and a bunch of cardboard.
This game is for sadists. How is this fun when all people do is try to screw over the other players?
Yay drafting euro combos. I guess there's no terrible artwork, at least.

I absolutely don't understand what the fuss is all about. Visually the tiles look completely unlike Portuguese tiles and mechanically it's absolutely dull and very unpredictable. If there's any strategy to this game I fail to see what it is. At least it plays quick.

There is usually something about a game that I like, but that's not the case with Azul. I find zero excitement in placing abstractly-patterned tiles into rows and columns for points, and though Azul poses as a light game, it really isn't. It's a sequencer, where you're thinking about possible sequences, over and over and over.
To calculate the sequences and make informed moves, and not just half-assed ones, you have to take into consideration what is happening on other player boards, and in anything but a drawn-out contest between two players (and there are so many more interesting games for that, chess, for starters), that is just too much information and calculation to process for a "light" game. This just gets worse and worse as the boards fill up, culminating in an endgame that promotes a downtime-inducing orgy of analysis as players calculate ways to avoid ending up with a bunch of negative points, and where one might even calculate final scores, given enough time or room for obstinacy.
This is a pure abstract calculation game, one I find both painful and completely uninteresting. I'd prefer playing Bingo, or War with 8 decks of cards, over another game of Azul.
Toooo light for board game fans

Waste of time and boring.
Much better games out there.
boring

A multiplayer variation on tit-for-tat. The primary aim is to build a column and hope no one else tries to build a similar column so you don't bump against them.

Probably good in 2-player.

==2021/04/10==
Nope. Asmodee games get 2s. Won't buy unless I can get for massive, massive discount.

==2020/12/08==
This is such an elegant design.

The rules are so easy to remember. Your turn is so fast and simple to resolve -- draft a color from a group, then add it to a row on your player board's queue. Scoring is (almost) completely intuitive.

And yet-- Despite how simply turns resolve, and despite how quickly play passes around the table, there is *so much* to think about. It's a deep game that I can play with anyone.

Azul is the kind of design that deserves to be mentioned in the same breath as Ticket to Ride, definitely. The design elegance, graphic design, and production are all top-notch. But I think that Azul is by *far* the better design.

I personally don't consider Azul an abstract. In my head, abstract games don't have drafting elements. Because of this, I consider Azul a direct competitor to Splendor and Century: Spice Road. I think I'll always prefer Azul to Splendor (but I haven't played anything from Century).

My geekbuddies tell me that the game is very cutthroat at 2p, and that sounds right to me. My first play just now was at 4p, and I was playing quickly with just my own tableau in mind. I would probably avoid playing this at 2p.

My initial reaction to LAMA was likewise absolutely ecstatic (rating it also a 10), and then I later cooled on the design (bringing it down to an 8). I will probably experience that same kind of arc here with Azul, if I get enough plays with it.

I'll likely take the same kind of stance on owning Azul as I did with Ticket to Ride -- not worth owning because everyone else around me will have a copy.

Also, regarding the insert: Ticket to Ride is secretly an extra $25 more expensive than the sticker price, because I had to replace the insert, buy an expansion for the regular-sized cards, and get custom tuckboxes for the deck. Azul... maybe... needs the plastic overlays from the expansion? (The scoring track on the top of the player boards was my biggest hesitation with Azul for the longest time) But otherwise, Azul is a complete product even off-the-shelf.

Played at a con. The game basically played itself. We wracked our brains trying to identify any possible strategy or player choice that would give player's some autonomy, but gave up. Every move was entirely predictable and obvious. Not sure why everyone loves this game. 2 plays.

Whatever this does, Qwirkle does it better. And I'm not a big fan of Qwirkle.

It's like all the joy of the engine builder type fiddling plus the joy of engine builder type interaction without the engine building. Yay! Which I guess makes for a lower overhead, more accessible experience. Actually the way how scoring snowballs shows at the traces of engine building still being in there.

Basically it's a game of glossing over the assembled tiles and player boards and constructing some 5-6 parallel data sequences in your mind and optimise around them. That's it. It's juggling with data that feels exactly like all the engine building games, without the engine building (though, scoring has the same dynamic). It's exactly what's been popular lately in euroblandia, only it's simpler (which is good) and as bland and devoid of any narrative. (Kingomino was better). So you're juggling this data in isolation of your mind, and possible somebody takes and action that makes you need to ditch 3 of the 6 equation sequences and build them anew (the horror! Oh, noes!). What's the point? There's no narrative. No sense of progression. Possibly interaction happens when people get on comparable levels of optimisation proficiency. Possibly.

Seems similar in interaction and supposed dickery to The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet - and that game looked WAY more charming, had less optimisashun of tedious data sequences, and had a narrative. A narrative!

Anyhow, high rating of 2.5 as maybe I would play it once more, with more players. (Above based on one 2 player game).
I feel like I have to work at getting points which is not appealing to me. Very little player interaction other than the end.
I don’t understand the hype on this one. Very light, completely obvious gameplay. Boring.

If you want mass market games in the same price range that are more fun and involve deeper strategy get Sagrada (gorgeous), Kingdomino or Queendomino, or even Splendor.

Not too bad, a low interaction drafting game, better on the reverse side where you can make your own patterns. There's not really much strategy, but quite tactical with plenty of hate drafting and there's a bit of gambling element trying to guess availability of tiles in later rounds, what your opponents are likely to take, etc. I think this is a superior game than 7 Wonders and which is in the same category I would argue.

At higher player counts, there isn't much control in terms of drafting tiles for max efficiency. You are quite often at the mercy of turn order and the level at which all players are lucid to each others board states. Sometimes, feels like the game is playing itself as the strategy is pretty straight forward (always build top 3 each round maximizing adjacency, fill bottom 2 to make complete columns for end game scoring).

Probably better at lower counts (as alluded to by bgg player preference survey), but at that point I'd rather play other things (this is usually a fun "light" party game in my playing contexts).

A great, simplistic design that makes for a wonderful experience at just about all player counts. Two-player especially becomes a nearly cutthroat experience, since you start drafting tiles that harm your opponent as much as they help you.

What I like:
- The tiles are beautiful and satisfying to handle.
- Simple rules but still some interesting decisions, especially around timing and denying tiles to others.

What I dislike:
- The punishment for leftover tiles can be pretty harsh.
- Lacks some excitement or tenseness that I enjoy in other games.

Why I culled it:
Azul is a solid game, but I just didn’t find myself excited to play it anymore. The decisions started to feel repetitive, and the interaction wasn’t quite enough to keep it interesting. If I want a quick abstract, I have others I’d rather pull out — ones with more variety or more player interaction. Azul’s not bad at all, just not one I needed to keep.
Tempted to get rid of.
very simple and broing
I'm not a big fan, just too basic. But it was worth buying the tiny travel size for, well, travel. The production is great for travel purposes!

after 2 games on BGA: The game has elegant mechanics and is visually so clear that you quickly see what’s going on. There’s definitely some thinking involved, but you can also play intuitively. Still, it didn’t keep me hooked. I simply didn’t find it appealing to play a full game and optimize my points. When the options for good moves narrow toward the end, I find that more annoying than exciting.
Few options to make truly impactful decisions. More or less plays itself with players of middling skill. Perhaps there is some tier of gameplay that I'm too dumb to access.

I played Azul once, found it to be a likeable abstract game with a straightforward puzzle built upon a easy-to-grasp drafting mechanism. I immediately forgot about it and later found out it's in the top 100. Interesting. The game's charme seems to stem from the fine intricacies of these pillars, whereas i would like there to be more depth to explore.

A solid design, and although games unfold differently, they do so in non-memorable ways, which is probably why my interest has waned over time. It’s a competitive abstract game at two players, and meaner than the theme suggests, but many 3-4 player games will be handed to one player simply due to the way player interests align.

A good, let's play something to kill time game. Not a marquee board game night play. Tiles and board feel high quality and it is aesthetically pleasing. Not a ton of overall strategy beyond some planning ahead. Minimal interaction between players other then some griefing by taking a tile someone else might want.

Don't forget about endgame scoring conditions LOL

Take tiles from the middle and pick which slot to put them in your play mat. What sets this apart is taking a color causes the remaining options to morph and the remaining turns to change, with players having to account for not gorging on too many tiles and also not being stuck last with a bad grab. Lovely chunky components that look like chocolates, and a nice feel reminiscent of Tetris-like puzzlers. The elegance helps it here and keeps the options clear.

4+2

Le jeu est simple et peut apporter son lot de moment de détentes et de partage, mais il peut aussi être très frustrant quand vous vous retrouvez dernier à prendre des tuiles ce qui est assez facile à calculer, surtout si vous êtes en concurrence sur une couleur. L'ordre de rotation de table devient donc essentiel, et le potentiel d'antijeu est ainsi trop important à mon goût. Il est assez simple d'envoyer 10 ou 15 points de pénalité à un adversaire et ainsi s'assurer une victoire assez facile et téléguidée après seulement deux ou trois manches.

Easy to learn abstract game with a surprising amount of depth. I enjoy the drafting mechanism where leftover tiles are placed in a common pool, as it allows for more tactical outmaneuvering. It can feel mathematical since you can map out the likely sequence of play. Not a huge fan of abstract games but this is a quick interactive puzzle with a lovely tactile feel that goes well with casual gamers.
Themeless drafting game that looks like a tile-laying game, but it isn't really. Strange placement rules and penalties, but it somehow works. I wish the player boards hadn't been identical.

Pros :
• Pleasant components to handle
• Lots of interaction in 2-player games with some hate-drafting
• Simple yet deep gameplay

Cons :
• Chaotic with 3 or 4 players
• Blue and red tiles lack patterns
• Lacks variety in player boards

Conclusion :
An elegant game that ends up feeling repetitive after several plays.

Such a great game! Doesn`t get boring. Like it with all player counts. The Mini version is also great and we like to take it on holidays.

Este é um jogo que não cansa de jogar nunca! Precisa ter estratégia, mas é muito leve e divertido! Costumo jogar com os meus pais entre uma partida de buraco e outra. Eles se divertem muito também! Contempla várias idades, não tem quem não goste. Se você ainda não conhece o jogo, eu sugiro que compra a versão "azul - mini" é igualzinho ao azul normal, mas menor, vem com um protetor em cada tabuleiro e é metade do preço! O custo-benefício é ótimo.

My in-laws decided to buy the game for themselves after playing 2 rounds.

That explains a lot.
one of my favorite games with an easy-to-learn premise and a high skill ceiling.

As far as gameplay is concerned, they could have just as easily gone with cardboard chits. But they didn't, and that gives Azul tremendous visual appeal that's definitely worth its cost.

 The rules are easy to learn, and there's more interaction involved than you'd guess at first glance: "Do you pick these tiles to score points, or the other tiles to deny your opponent a good scoring opportunity?"

 Scales very well with different player counts.

 It has built-in revitalization of gameplay: once it starts getting stale, you flip your board to the side without pre-printed patterns.

Also includes:
- Azul: Joker Tiles
